questions.text: A patient who is a primipara is experiencing an aggravation of hearing impairment during her pregnancy. Rinne's test yields negative results in both ears, and Weber's test indicates lateralization to the right side. Upon otoscopy, the tympanic membranes appear normal. Audiometry reveals a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz. What treatment would be most suitable for this particular condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Stapedotomy

 

The given clinical presentation strongly indicates otosclerosis as the diagnosis, and the preferred treatment for this condition is stapedotomy an effective surgical treatment for otosclerosis, often preferred over stapedectomy due to a lower risk of complications and similar efficacy in restoring hearing

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium fluoride: Once a common medical treatment for otosclerosis, though now largely considered obsolete due to less satisfactory long-term outcomes compared to surgical interventions.

 

Option B. Tympanoplasty: This procedure is used to reconstruct the tympanic membrane and middle ear ossicles but is not indicated for otosclerosis, which does not typically affect the tympanic membrane integrity.

 

Option C. Stapedectomy: surgical treatment for otosclerosis, but less preferred over stapedotomy due to high risk of complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with otosclerosis, especially during pregnancy, stapedotomy is the recommended treatment to address conductive hearing loss effectively. These surgical options are typically preferred over medical management with sodium fluoride due to better auditory outcomes and more definitive resolution of conductive hearing impairments.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female took aspirin for headache and she developed wheezing and breathlessness. This will be associated with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nasal Polyp

 

The clinical scenario described is indicative of a condition known as Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD), commonly known as Samter’s triad. This condition is characterized by:

 

  • Asthma
  • Nasal polyposis (particularly ethmoidal polyps)
  • Sensitivity to aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)

 

When individuals with this triad ingest aspirin, they can experience severe respiratory reactions including nasal congestion, asthma attacks, and even anaphylaxis. This reaction is not mediated by IgE, which is the common pathway for allergic reactions, but through alterations in leukotriene and prostaglandin metabolism.

 

Details on Nasal Polyps:

 

  • Nasal polyps are benign growths that occur in the lining of the nasal passages or sinuses.
  • They are associated with chronic inflammation and are often seen in conditions like chronic rhinosinusitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased IgE: While increased IgE is typical of allergic reactions (allergic asthma, allergic rhinitis), AERD is a non-IgE mediated reaction.

 

Option C. Extrinsic asthma: Also known as allergic asthma, it involves an IgE-mediated response to external allergens, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Drug interaction: While the symptoms can be perceived as a drug interaction, they are actually a specific pharmacological reaction to NSAIDs in patients with AERD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the link between aspirin ingestion and respiratory symptoms in patients with nasal polyps is crucial for managing their condition effectively. Patients diagnosed with AERD should avoid NSAIDs and may need specific treatments for asthma and nasal polyps, along with alternatives to NSAIDs for pain management.

 

Samter’s triad: Asthma, Nasal polyposis (ethmoidal), Aspirin hypersensitivity

choices.text: Making him sit in front row in class

questions.text: A child has bilateral SNHL. Which of the following is not preferred in the child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

Adenoidectomy with Grommet Insertion: This procedure is primarily used to treat chronic adenoiditis and otitis media with effusion (OME), which are associated with conductive hearing loss (CHL), not SNHL. Since the child has SNHL, this treatment is not appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) indicates that there is a problem in the inner ear (cochlea) or the auditory nerve. When treating bilateral SNHL in a child, certain interventions are preferred based on the underlying pathology and the severity of the hearing loss.

 

Option A. Cochlear Implant: This is a viable option for children with severe to profound SNHL where the cochlea is affected but the auditory nerve is intact. The implant bypasses the damaged cochlea and directly stimulates the auditory nerve, allowing the child to hear.

 

Option C. Making him sit in front row in class: This is a common accommodation to help children with hearing loss to better hear and engage in classroom activities. It minimizes the distance between the child and the teacher, thus reducing the impact of hearing loss.

 

Option D.  Hearing Aid: This is suitable for children with mild to moderate SNHL. Hearing aids amplify sounds, making them louder and easier to hear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is not preferred for treating bilateral sensorineural hearing loss as it addresses conditions causing conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: Laryngismus stridulus is due to deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Laryngismus stridulus, also known as spasmodic croup, is characterized by sudden onset of apnea and a loud stridor due to respiratory obstruction caused by laryngospasm. This condition is often associated with rickets, which is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D. Rickets leads to softening and weakening of the bones in children, and it can also cause disturbances in the metabolism of calcium and phosphorus, leading to neuromuscular irritability, which in turn can result in laryngospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects the eyes, leading to conditions such as night blindness and xerophthalmia. It does not cause laryngismus stridulus.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency is rare and typically presents with neurological symptoms due to its role as an antioxidant. It does not cause laryngismus stridulus.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency leads to bleeding disorders because of its role in the synthesis of clotting factors. It is not associated with laryngismus stridulus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngismus stridulus, characterized by sudden respiratory obstruction and stridor, is associated with rickets caused by Vitamin D deficiency. Recognizing the link between Vitamin D deficiency and laryngismus stridulus is important for diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with a history of nasal obstruction for the last 2 months. A CT scan was done, and the following findings are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antrochoanal polyp

 

The CT scan shows a mass originating from the maxillary sinus extending into the choana and nasopharynx, indicative of an antrochoanal polyp. Antrochoanal polyps are benign lesions that arise from the maxillary sinus, extend through the sinus ostium, and grow into the nasopharynx. This causes nasal obstruction, which aligns with the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid hypertrophy: Adenoid hypertrophy occurs in the nasopharynx and is characterized by enlarged adenoids, leading to nasal obstruction and mouth breathing. It does not typically present with a mass extending from the maxillary sinus.

 

Option B. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma: This is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that occurs predominantly in adolescent males. It arises from the nasopharynx and extends into adjacent areas, not from the maxillary sinus.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: This malignant tumor arises from the epithelial cells of the nasopharynx. It usually presents with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The mass in the CT scan originating from the maxillary sinus is not consistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

An antrochoanal polyp originates from the maxillary sinus and extends through the choana into the nasopharynx, causing nasal obstruction. The presence of a gap between the tumor and the posterior pharyngeal wall on imaging, known as the "dot sign," supports this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man visited the clinic, reporting intermittent episodes of vertigo, a feeling of pressure and fullness in the ear, reduced hearing, and a low-tone roaring tinnitus. What potential clinical condition could be considered as a diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Meniere’s disease

 

The most likely conclusion points to Meniere's disease, alternatively referred to as endolymphatic hydrops.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV): Characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to changes in head position. It does not typically involve hearing loss or tinnitus.

 

Option C. Labyrinthitis: Involves continuous, not episodic vertigo that usually lasts for days and is accompanied by more pervasive auditory and balance disturbances.

 

Option D. Syncope: Refers to a sudden loss of consciousness and posture, generally caused by a decrease in blood flow to the brain, not typically associated with auditory symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meniere’s disease is a complex inner ear disorder that requires careful management to control symptoms and prevent progression. Treatment strategies focus on relieving the symptoms and, in severe cases, may involve surgical interventions to reduce the endolymphatic pressure or decompress the endolymphatic sac. Patients benefit from a multi-disciplinary approach involving audiologists, otolaryngologists, and sometimes neurologists.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the right ear which is slowly progressive. She also has tinnitus which is pulsatile in nature. On examination, a reddish mass was seen behind the tympanic membrane and an audible bruit is heard over the mastoid when auscultation with a stethoscope. Her Rinne test was negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Glomus tumor

 

The given clinical picture suggests a diagnosis of a 'glomus tumor'

 

Glomus tumor

 

It is the most common benign neoplasm of middle ear and is so-named because of its origin from the glomus bodies.

 

The tumour consists of paraganglionic cells derived from the neural crest.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSOM patients on examination shows presence of granulations, in-growth of squamous epithelium from the edges of perforation, tympanosclerosis and adhesions.

 

Option B. Acute suppurative otitis media is an acute inflammation of middle ear by pyogenic organisms. Tympanic membrane is retracted with handle of malleus assuming a more horizontal position, prominence of lateral process of malleus and loss of light reflex. A cart-wheel appearance can be appreciated in later stages.

 

 

Option C. Mastoiditis leads to features like pain behind ear, fever, ear discharge. Mastoid surface looks smooth and shiny, so often called as ‘ironed out mastoid’. On otoscopy, light house sign & sagging of posterior meatal wall seen.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a reddish, pulsating mass behind the tympanic membrane, along with conductive hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus in a middle-aged female, is highly indicative of a glomus tumor, particularly glomus tympanicum. Prompt referral for appropriate imaging and specialist evaluation is essential for accurate diagnosis and management.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 121,122

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy fell from the bed and developed swelling in the nose and difficulty in breathing. Examination revealed smooth rounded swellings on either side of the septum, through both the nares. On palpation, it was soft and fluctuant. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Incision and drainage

 

The presence of a history of trauma, coupled with bilateral septal swelling, indicates a possible septal hematoma. This condition is typically treated by performing incision and drainage of the hematoma.

 

Incision and Drainage: This is the most appropriate initial management step for a septal hematoma because it promptly relieves the pressure from the accumulated blood, preventing further complications like cartilage destruction or infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic Antibiotics: While important, antibiotics alone would not address the immediate problem of the hematoma; they are typically used post-drainage to prevent secondary infection.

 

Option C. High-resolution Computerized Tomography (CT): While helpful for assessing complex facial fractures, a CT scan is not necessary in this straightforward case of suspected septal hematoma without evidence of further complications or other injuries.

 

Option D. Submucosal Resection: This surgical procedure is used for correcting nasal septum deviations but is not appropriate for treating a septal hematoma.

 

Educational Objective:
 

 

Reference - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 168

choices.text: Both Vocal cords involved and fixed
Both Vocal cords involved and mobile
One Vocal cord involved and fixed
One Vocal cord involved and mobile

questions.text: Mark the correct description for laryngeal cancer stage T1b N0 M0.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both vocal cords involved and mobile

 

T1b in Laryngeal Cancer refers to the tumor involving both vocal cords but still maintaining mobility. This indicates that the cancer is localized to the vocal cords without extending into other areas that would restrict their movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both Vocal cords involved and fixed: This would typically be classified under T3 or higher, depending on the extent of fixation and additional features.

 

Option C. One Vocal cord involved and fixed: Would be classified as T3 due to the fixation of the vocal cord, indicating more advanced local disease.

 

Option D. One Vocal cord involved and mobile: This corresponds to T1a, indicating a more limited disease confined to one vocal cord but not affecting mobility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TNM staging for CA Larynx:

 

  • T1 – only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis)
  • T2 – involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility.
  • T3 – involving pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords.
  • T4a – local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx
  • T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc)
  • N0 – no cervical lymph nodes
  • N1 – single ipsilateral < 3cm
  • N2 – single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm
  • N3 – single or multiple nodes > 6cm
  • M0 – no metastasis
  • M1 – metastasis present

choices.text: Surgical management is required in most children

questions.text: Which of the following is true about laryngomalacia? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Most common in newborn

 

Laryngomalacia is indeed most common in newborns and is often noticed shortly after birth. It is the most common cause of stridor in infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngomalacia typically presents with inspiratory stridor, not expiratory. This stridor is due to the collapse of supraglottic structures during inhalation.

 

Option B. The stridor of laryngomalacia typically worsens in the supine position. This is because the supraglottic structures are more likely to collapse into the airway when a child is lying on their back.

 

Option D. Most children with laryngomalacia do not require surgical management. The condition is often self-limiting and tends to improve as the child grows and the laryngeal structures become more rigid, usually by 18 to 24 months of age. Surgery is reserved for severe cases where there are feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, severe stridor, or apnea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngomalacia is characterized by inspiratory stridor that typically worsens in the supine position and is most commonly diagnosed in newborns. The condition generally resolves on its own without the need for surgical intervention in most cases.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. He also complained of nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

The history of a juvenile male with recurrent spontaneous epistaxis and nasal obstruction is suggestive of juvenile angiofibroma.

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

  • Most common benign tumor of nasopharynx.
  • Site of origin: sphenopalatine foramen.
  • It is highly vascular tumor. vessels are just endothelium-lined spaces with no elastic or muscle coat. This accounts for the severe bleeding as the vessels lose the ability to contract; also, the bleeding cannot be controlled by application of adrenaline, hence biopsy is contraindicated.

 

Extensions of JNA

 

  1. Nasal cavity causing nasal obstruction, epistaxis and nasal discharge.
  2. Paranasal sinuses. Maxillary, sphenoid and ethmoid sinuses can all be invaded.
  3. Pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa and cheek.
  4. Orbits giving rise to proptosis and “frog-face deformity.” It enters through the inferior orbital fissure and also destroys apex of the orbit. It can also enter the orbit through superior orbital fissure.
  5. Cranial cavity. It can extend into:
  6. Anterior cranial fossa through roof of ethmoids or cribriform plate.
  7. Middle cranial fossa through erosion of floor of middle cranial fossa or indirectly by invading the sphenoid sinus and Sella turcica. In the former case, tumor lies lateral to internal carotid artery and in the latter case medial to the artery

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Adolescent male
  • Profuse spontaneous recurrent epistaxis
  • Nasal obstruction with denasal speech
  • Conductive hearing loss due to tubal block

 

 

  • Other clinical features like broadening of nasal bridge, proptosis, swelling of cheek, infratemporal fossa or involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth and VIth cranial nerves will depend on the extent of tumor.

 

 

Treatment – Surgical excision is treatment of choice.

 

Investigation:

 

CECT (contrast enhanced CT) - This shows Hollman miller sign or antral sign i.e., anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus MRI is complementary to CT scan Angiography – to assess blood supply of tumor. Feeding vessels should be embolized preoperatively

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with Painless cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal obstruction, rhinolalia clausa, unilateral hearing loss of conductive type due to serous otitis media caused by ET obstruction

 

Option B. Rhabdomyosarcoma arises from the embryonic muscles tissue or the pluripotent mesenchyme. In early stages, it mimics chronic suppurative otitis media with ear discharge, polyp or granulations.

 

 

Option C. Pyogenic granuloma is a reactive granuloma usually occurs in response to trauma or chronic irritation. It mostly involves anterior gingivae but sometimes the other sites such as tongue, buccal mucosa or lips.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma should be strongly considered in adolescent males presenting with unexplained, recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction, especially when a nasopharyngeal mass is identified. Prompt and thorough diagnostic imaging followed by surgical planning is essential for effective management of this condition.

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal obstruction after being hit on the face from the front. On examination, a boggy swelling of the septum is seen on both sides (see picture below), which is fluctuant on palpation with a swab or blunt probe. He should be managed by?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Incision & Drainage

 

Explanation: 

 

The patient presents with nasal obstruction and a boggy, fluctuant swelling of the septum on both sides after trauma, which indicates a septal hematoma. A septal hematoma is a collection of blood within the septal tissues and requires immediate drainage to prevent complications such as infection, abscess formation, or septal cartilage necrosis. The definitive treatment is incision and drainage to evacuate the collected blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal packing: Nasal packing is not the treatment of choice for a septal hematoma. It is typically used for controlling nasal bleeding (epistaxis).

 

Option C. Antibiotics: While antibiotics may be used to prevent secondary infection, they do not address the primary issue of the hematoma and are not the definitive treatment.

 

Option D. Nasal decongestants: Nasal decongestants are used to reduce nasal mucosal swelling and congestion but are not effective in treating a septal hematoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A septal hematoma, characterized by a boggy, fluctuant swelling of the septum after nasal trauma, should be treated with immediate incision and drainage to prevent complications and ensure proper healing.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about function of utricle and saccule? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Linear acceleration

 

The utricle and saccule are part of the vestibular system in the inner ear, which is primarily responsible for maintaining balance and orientation. They do not participate in the hearing process but are involved in sensing linear accelerations.

 

  • Utricle: Senses horizontal linear movements.
  • Saccule: Senses vertical linear movements.

 

Both structures contain sensory epithelia known as the maculae, which house hair cells that respond to shifts in movement through the displacement of tiny stones called otoliths on a gel-like layer.

 

Semicircular canals sense the Angular movements.

 

Hearing is sensed by Organ of Corti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hearing high frequency sounds & C. Hearing low frequency sounds: These functions are attributed to the cochlea, where sound vibrations are converted into nerve signals that are interpreted by the brain. High and low frequency sound detection is facilitated by different regions of the cochlear basilar membrane.

 

Option D. Angular acceleration: This is the specific function of the semicircular canals, which are filled with fluid and contain sensory hair cells that respond to the rotation of the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The utricle and saccule are essential for detecting linear movements, helping the body maintain balance and posture in response to everyday activities and motion, while the cochlea and semicircular canals perform separate functions related to hearing and angular motion detection, respectively.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with hoarseness of voice with a history of significant weight loss. On laryngoscopy, ulceroproliferative growth involving the left vocal fold is seen, as shown below. The vocal cord is fixed. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total Laryngectomy with Neck Dissection.

 

Explanation:  


The clinical presentation (hoarseness of voice, weight loss) and the laryngoscopic findings (ulceroproliferative growth with fixed vocal cord) suggest advanced glottic carcinoma. The fixed vocal cord indicates at least T3 stage, as it suggests tumor infiltration into the paraglottic space or fixation due to deeper invasion. Weight loss in an elderly patient further supports an advanced stage malignancy.

 

This is the preferred treatment for T3 or T4 laryngeal cancers, especially when the vocal cords are fixed, and there is a high likelihood of regional spread. If the patient has significant lymph node involvement or is symptomatic (e.g., weight loss), a neck dissection is warranted along with total laryngectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical Radiotherapy: Radical radiotherapy is usually preferred for early-stage laryngeal cancers (T1 or T2) with mobile vocal cords. It is less effective for advanced stages (T3 or T4) due to higher chances of recurrence.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the primary treatment for advanced laryngeal carcinoma unless the patient is unsuitable for surgery or radiation. It is primarily used for palliative care or in cases with distant metastasis.

 

Option D. Concurrent Chemoradiation: Concurrent chemoradiation is a consideration for organ preservation in advanced laryngeal cancers. However, for patients with a fixed vocal cord and significant weight loss, total laryngectomy provides better local control and survival outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:


For advanced glottic carcinoma with vocal cord fixation (T3/T4) and evidence of regional spread, the best treatment option is Total Laryngectomy with Neck Dissection.

choices.text: Bleeding is from the adjacent invading vessels

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. On examination, following was seen on the CECT. All are false except: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tumor vessel lack contractility

 

Based on the provided CT image and the clinical context of recurrent bleeding, the most accurate statement is Tumor vessels lack contractility, which contributes to the propensity for bleeding in tumorous growths.

 

"Tumor vessel lack contractility" is a true statement about tumor vessels. They are often abnormally formed, with poor structural integrity and can lack the ability to contract, which normally helps control bleeding when vessels are injured.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outgrown the blood supply: Suggests that the lesion has grown faster than the blood vessels can proliferate to support it. This can lead to areas of necrosis within tumours.

 

Option C. Bleeding is from the adjacent invading vessels: Implies that the normal vessels adjacent to the tumor are the source of bleeding. However, the bleeding associated with tumors is usually due to the tumor vessels themselves because they are prone to rupture, not the adjacent normal vessels.

 

Option D. Lacks capsule: May or may not be true depending on the type of tumor. Some benign tumors have a well-defined capsule, while malignant tumors often lack a capsule. However, this option does not directly relate to the issue of bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor vessels are known to lack contractility, which contributes to the risk of bleeding associated with tumors, as they cannot constrict effectively to stop blood flow when damaged.

questions.text: A teacher presented with complaints of hoarseness of voice. On examination, bilateral swelling was noted on anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vocal nodule 

 

Clinical history suggests a most probable diagnosis of vocal nodule

 

Vocal Nodules (aka Singer's nodule/Teacher's nodule)

 

Pathogenesis – Trauma → submucosal oedema & hemorrhage → hyalinization & fibrosis

 

Site: appear symmetrically on the free edge of vocal cord, at junction of anterior 1/3rd & posterior 2/3rd of vocal cord (Bilateral) as this is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus subject to maximum trauma

 

Clinical feature – Hoarseness, Vocal fatigue and pain in the neck on prolonged phonation are other common symptoms.

 

Treatment - Voice rest, Speech therapy, Micro laryngeal surgery if persistent

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal Polyp is an exophytic lesion with thin mucosa, caused by sudden shouting. Presents with Hoarseness of voice, Diplophonia (double voice).

 

 

Option C. Vocal Cyst are retention cysts occur in false vocal cords.

 

Option D. Reinke’s edema is Diffuse collection of oedema fluid in sub-epithelial space, MC in smokers. On examination, saddle-bag appearance of vocal cords on laryngoscopy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal nodules are common in individuals who frequently use their voices intensely, and they require a combination of vocal rest, speech therapy, and possibly surgical intervention to manage effectively and prevent recurrence.

choices.text: Antibiotics and Peroral Incision and Drainage

questions.text: A child presented to your clinic with complaints of severe respiratory distress, chin swelling, and difficulty in opening mouth. He gives a history of dental infection a week ago. Examination findings given below. What is the next step in management? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tracheostomy

 

Explanation:

 

The child presents with severe respiratory distress and swelling suggestive of Ludwig's angina, a severe cellulitis of the submandibular space. This condition can rapidly compromise the airway by pushing the anterior respiratory wall posteriorly, leading to obstruction. Given the severity of the respiratory distress, securing the airway is the priority, and tracheostomy is the recommended emergency procedure to ensure an adequate airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early intubation: While securing the airway is critical, intubation can be challenging and potentially hazardous in the presence of significant submandibular swelling.

 

Option B. External Incision and Drainage: This may be necessary after securing the airway but is not the immediate step in severe respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Antibiotics and Peroral Incision and Drainage: Antibiotics are essential, but in the acute setting of airway compromise, they do not provide immediate relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe respiratory distress due to Ludwig's angina, a tracheostomy is the immediate step to secure the airway and prevent obstruction.

questions.text: What is the Battle sign? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mastoid ecchymosis   

 

Battle's sign is characterized by ecchymosis (bruising) over the mastoid process, which is located just behind the ear. This sign is typically associated with fractures of the temporal bone. The presence of such bruising is a delayed symptom that generally appears several hours to days after the injury and serves as a clinical indicator of the fracture's extent and location, potentially involving the base of the skull.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Periorbital hematoma: Also known as "raccoon eyes," this refers to bruising around the eyes and is another sign that can be associated with base of skull fractures but is not indicative of the specific location over the mastoid process.

 

Option C. Bezold abscess: This is an infection that spreads from the middle ear to involve the mastoid process and surrounding tissues, leading to a collection of pus. Unlike Battle's sign, this is an infectious process, not a direct sign of a fracture.

 

Option D. Perichondritis: This is an infection of the cartilage and surrounding tissue of the ear, typically caused by bacterial infection. It presents with pain, redness, and swelling around the cartilage of the ear but does not relate to temporal bone fractures or manifest as ecchymosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battle’s sign is ecchymosis over the mastoid seen in fractures of temporal bone

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 507

questions.text: A young woman visited the ENT OPD reporting a sudden onset of hearing loss in one ear, accompanied by tinnitus and dizziness. This occurred after experiencing an episode of acute otitis media two weeks ago. During her initial visit, the Rinne test and fistula test showed positive results, but she declined treatment at that time. Now, she returned with aggravated hearing loss in the same ear. Upon examination, the fistula test yielded negative results. Considering the situation, what would be the most probable result on the Rinne test in this case? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. False negative

 

The given clinical history suggests severe sensorineural hearing loss secondary to untreated suppurative labyrinthitis, hence Rinne’s test will be false negative.

 

Positive fistula test and Rinne’s positive test in the beginning suggests a functional labyrinth along with normal or early sensorineural hearing loss respectively.

 

False Negative Rinne is seen in severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Patient does not perceive any sound of tuning fork by air conduction but responds to bone conduction testing. This response to bone conduction from the opposite ear because of transcranial transmission of sound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 24

questions.text: A 7-year-old male presents to the ER with a two-day history of worsening ear pain and drainage. He was evaluated in the clinic 5 days ago and diagnosed with acute right otitis media. He was placed on amoxicillin and he initially appeared to improve until two days ago when his ear pain recurred and this is now accompanied by ear drainage, redness behind his right ear, and a prominent right pinna which is pointing down and out as shown below. The most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute Mastoiditis

 

The patient's presentation of worsening ear pain, drainage, and redness behind the ear, along with a prominent right pinna pointing down and out, is indicative of a complication of acute otitis media, specifically acute mastoiditis. Acute mastoiditis is characterized by inflammation and infection of the mastoid air cells, often resulting in a post-auricular abscess, as seen in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis externa: Otitis externa, or external ear canal infection, typically presents with pain, discharge, and sometimes swelling of the ear canal, but does not usually cause post-auricular redness or a displaced pinna.

 

Option B. Otitis media with effusion: Otitis media with effusion involves the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It does not present with post-auricular redness or abscess.

 

Option D. Coalescent Mastoiditis: Coalescent mastoiditis is a more advanced stage of mastoiditis where the bony septa between mastoid air cells break down, forming a common cavity. This diagnosis could be considered if the condition had been present for a longer duration. However, the acute presentation described fits acute mastoiditis more accurately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media, can present with post-auricular redness, abscess, and displacement of the pinna, requiring prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A female presents with complaints of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. Rinne’s test reveals conductive hearing loss. On otoscopy, a red and bulgy mass behind the intact tympanic membrane is observed. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Glomus tumor

 

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of glomus tumor

 

Glomus tumor

 

It is the most common benign neoplasm of middle ear and is so-named because of its origin from the glomus bodies.

 

The tumor consists of paraganglionic cells derived from the neural crest.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serous otitis media: Typically presents with an effusion in the middle ear without signs of infection, leading to a dull or amber appearance of the tympanic membrane rather than a red mass.

 

Option C. Chronic otitis media: Characterized by persistent ear infections and can include a perforated tympanic membrane or cholesteatoma, not typically presenting as a red mass.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: Affects the ossicles, particularly the stapes, and leads to conductive hearing loss. It does not present as a visible mass in the ear canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a red, pulsatile mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in a patient with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss is highly suggestive of a glomus tympanicum tumor, requiring detailed imaging for confirmation and planning of appropriate intervention strategies.

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with hearing difficulty. On examination, the Rinne test is positive in the right ear and negative in the left ear. Weber's test shows lateralization to the right. Bone conduction is reduced in the left ear and normal in the right ear. What is the most likely interpretation of these findings? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

 

Explanation: 


The findings indicate severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear because:

 

  • Left ear shows Rinne negative test (false negative)
  • Weber lateralizes to right (better hearing) ear
  • Reduced bone conduction in left ear confirms inner ear pathology
  • This pattern occurs in severe unilateral SNHL where: 
    • Sound during bone conduction testing crosses to the normal ear (cross hearing)
    • Creates false impression of bone conduction better than air conduction
    • True pathology revealed by Weber test lateralizing away from affected ear
    • Reduced bone conduction confirms SNHL

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conductive hearing loss in the left ear

 

  • Would show true Rinne negative
  • Weber would lateralize to affected (left) ear
  • Bone conduction would be normal

 

Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear

 

  • Rinne would be positive in right ear (correct)
  • Weber would lateralize to left (unaffected) ear
  • Bone conduction would be reduced in right ear

 

Option C. Conductive hearing loss in the right ear

 

  • Rinne would be negative in right ear
  • Weber would lateralize to right ear
  • Bone conduction would be normal

 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative Rinne test with reduced bone conduction and Weber’s test lateralizing to the opposite ear suggests sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in the affected ear.

choices.text: Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks
IV antibiotics and follow up after a month

questions.text: A child presents with foul-smelling ear discharge. On further exploration, a small perforation is found in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane as shown below. Most appropriate management would be: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tympanomastoid exploration

 

The child presents with foul-smelling ear discharge and a small perforation in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane, indicating an attic perforation. This condition is consistent with attico-antral chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), also known as unsafe CSOM. This type of CSOM is characterized by scanty, mucopurulent, foul-smelling discharge, which may sometimes be bloodstained.

 

The definitive management for attico-antral CSOM is tympanomastoid exploration. This procedure helps to eradicate the disease from the middle ear and mastoid, preventing further complications such as cholesteatoma and hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks: While topical antibiotics can be used to manage the discharge and infection initially, they are not the definitive treatment for attico-antral CSOM. The primary goal is to control the infection, but definitive surgical intervention is required for complete management.

 

Option B. IV antibiotics and follow up after a month: IV antibiotics may be used in severe cases to control acute infection, but they are not the standard approach for managing attico-antral CSOM. Follow-up after a month without addressing the underlying condition is not adequate.

 

Option C. Tympanoplasty: Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure aimed at repairing the tympanic membrane and is typically used in cases of safe CSOM or tubotympanic CSOM. It is not appropriate for attico-antral CSOM, where more extensive surgical intervention is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attico-antral CSOM, characterized by foul-smelling discharge and attic perforation, requires tympanomastoid exploration for definitive management.

questions.text: Identify the fracture shown in the image below. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chevallet fracture

 

The image shows a Chevallet fracture pattern. Chevallet fracture is a type of maxillofacial fracture that commonly occurs due to trauma. This type of fracture typically affects the lower jaw (mandible) and is characterized by a specific pattern of breakage along the jawline, often due to a direct impact. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Jarjaway fracture: Also known as J-type fracture, has a different fracture line pattern than what was shown in the image.

 

Option C. C-shaped fracture: Has a curved fracture line resembling the letter C, which is different from the pattern shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained
Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss
Associated Ménière's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery
Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant patient presented with complaints of worsening of hearing since the onset of pregnancy. On PTA the following graph was obtained. Which of the following statements regarding the disease is true? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery

 

Explanation:

 

The patient, being pregnant and experiencing worsening hearing loss, suggests otosclerosis. The provided PTA (Pure Tone Audiogram) shows a significant air-bone gap on the right side, indicating conductive hearing loss, which is consistent with otosclerosis.

 

Definitely, air travel is contraindicated for patients post-stapedectomy for at least three months. The variations in middle ear pressure during ascent and descent can lead to displacement or dislocation of the prosthetic piston used in the surgery, making this statement true.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained: In otosclerosis, an As type of tympanogram (indicating reduced compliance of the middle ear system) is typically obtained, not Ad. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

 

Option B. Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss: A notch at 2000Hz on bone conduction is known as Carhart's notch, which is indicative of otosclerosis, not noise-induced hearing loss. Noise-induced hearing loss typically presents a notch at 4000Hz. Hence, this statement is incorrect.

 

Option C. Associated Ménière's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery: Ménière's disease is indeed a contraindication for stapes surgery. The presence of Ménière's disease can lead to complications such as irritation of the saccule during the surgery, causing vertigo and giddiness. Thus, this statement is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Air travel is contraindicated for at least three months post-stapedectomy due to the risk of pressure-induced displacement or dislocation of the surgical prosthesis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented to ENT OPD with severe dysphagia of recent onset and muffled voice. On examination, a cherry red swollen epiglottis was seen behind the tongue. On X-ray, the following finding is seen. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute epiglottitis

 

Explanation: 

 

The child presents with severe dysphagia, a muffled voice, and a cherry red swollen epiglottis, which are classic signs of acute epiglottitis. The X-ray shows the characteristic "thumb sign," indicating a swollen epiglottis. Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency and requires immediate attention. The child will typically sit in the tripod position to help keep the airway open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute laryngotracheobronchitis: Also known as croup, this condition typically presents with a barking cough and stridor. The X-ray shows the "steeple sign," which is not seen here.

 

Option C. Acute laryngitis: Acute laryngitis involves inflammation of the vocal cords, leading to hoarseness, but does not typically cause severe dysphagia or a swollen epiglottis.

 

Option D. Syphilis larynx: Syphilis affecting the larynx is rare and presents with different symptoms, such as hoarseness or a sore throat, rather than an acute swollen epiglottis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute epiglottitis presents with severe dysphagia, muffled voice, and a cherry red swollen epiglottis. The "thumb sign" on X-ray is a characteristic finding, and immediate medical intervention is necessary.

questions.text: Constituents of nasal septum include all except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perpendicular plate of palatine

 

Explanation: 

 

The nasal septum is composed of both bony and cartilaginous components. The main constituents include the perpendicular plate of ethmoid bone superiorly, the vomer posteroinferiorly, the quadrangular cartilage anteriorly, and the maxillary crest inferiorly. The perpendicular plate of the palatine bone is not a constituent of the nasal septum.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vomer: This is a correct component of the nasal septum. The vomer is a thin, flat bone that forms the posteroinferior portion of the nasal septum. It articulates with the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid superiorly and the maxillary crest inferiorly.

 

Option C. Quadrangular cartilage: This is a correct component of the nasal septum. The quadrangular cartilage (septal cartilage) forms the major anterior portion of the nasal septum. It is attached to the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid posterosuperiorly and to the vomer posteroinferiorly.

 

Option D. Maxillary crest: This is a correct component of the nasal septum. The maxillary crest forms a ridge along the nasal floor that supports the inferior edge of the nasal septum. It is formed by the fusion of the palatine processes of the maxillae.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The nasal septum consists of the perpendicular plate of ethmoid bone, vomer, quadrangular cartilage, and maxillary crest, but does not include the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone.

questions.text: Which of the following tumors arises from the olfactory nasal mucosa? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Esthesioneuroblastoma

 

Explanation:


Esthesioneuroblastoma, also called olfactory neuroblastoma, specifically arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of the nasal cavity. It is also known as olfactory placode tumor, highlighting its origin from the specialized olfactory mucosa. This tumor typically presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis, and can invade surrounding structures including the orbit and intracranial cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal Glioma: This is a congenital lesion that represents entrapped neural tissue during embryonic development. It doesn't arise from the olfactory mucosa but is a developmental anomaly. Nasal gliomas are typically seen in infants and children and may be extranasal (60%), intranasal (30%) or both (10%).

 

Option B. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: This tumor arises from the glands of the mucous membrane or minor salivary glands, rather than from the olfactory epithelium. It typically involves the upper part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity but is not derived from olfactory tissue.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: This tumor originates from the epithelial lining of the nasopharynx, not from the olfactory mucosa in the nasal cavity. It arises from a completely different anatomical site.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Esthesioneuroblastoma is a distinctive neoplasm that uniquely originates from the specialized olfactory epithelium in the upper nasal cavity, making it the only true tumor of olfactory mucosal origin among the options provided.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on this image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

 

The image shows a chest X-ray with dextrocardia, a condition where the heart is positioned on the right side of the chest. This is a key feature of situs inversus, which is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome.

 

Kartagener syndrome is characterized by a triad of clinical features: recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. The presence of situs inversus, as indicated by dextrocardia on the X-ray, is a distinguishing feature that confirms the diagnosis of Kartagener syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the lungs and digestive system, characterized by thick, sticky mucus that can clog the airways and lead to infections. It does not typically present with situs inversus or dextrocardia.

 

Option C. Young syndrome: Young syndrome also involves recurrent sinusitis and bronchiectasis, similar to Kartagener syndrome. However, it is distinguished by infertility due to azoospermia rather than situs inversus. The absence of dextrocardia or situs inversus on imaging excludes Young syndrome as the correct answer.

 

Option D. Atrophic rhinitis: Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by chronic nasal inflammation leading to crusting, foul-smelling nasal discharge, nasal block, and enlarged nasal cavities. It does not involve bronchiectasis, recurrent sinusitis, or situs inversus, making it unrelated to the features seen in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:


Kartagener syndrome is identified by the presence of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (including dextrocardia), which is clearly visible in the chest X-ray provided.

choices.text: Derived from pouch of 1st and 2nd arches

questions.text: A patient presents with repeated infections from the lesion shown in the image. The correct statement in relation to the image is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Derived from 1st and 2nd arches

 

Given the location of the lesion near the ear and the recurrent infections which are characteristic of a preauricular sinus, the correct statement is Option C. Derived from 1st and 2nd arches.

 

These lesions are ectodermal in origin and are related to the developmental defects of the first and second branchial arches, which also contribute to the formation of the auricle (external ear).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. "Derived from first cleft" refers to structures that develop from the first branchial cleft in embryonic development. External ear structures, such as the external auditory canal, are derived from the first cleft, but preauricular sinuses are not typically included in this category.

 

Option B. "Derived from pouch of 1st and 2nd arches" refers to internal structures of the ear that can be affected by branchial pouch anomalies. However, preauricular sinuses are not associated with the internal structures derived from the pouches.

 

Option D. "Derived from 3rd and 4th arches" is incorrect for preauricular lesions. The third and fourth branchial arches contribute to the development of parts of the hyoid bone and the structures of the neck, not the external ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preauricular sinuses or cysts are congenital lesions derived from the first and second branchial arches and are associated with the external ear, often presenting with recurrent infections

questions.text: An elderly male presents with a history of dysphagia, regurgitation, foul breath, and cough. Bilateral lung crepitations are noted on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zenker's Diverticulum

 

Explanation:


Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum that occurs when pharyngeal mucosa herniates through Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between the two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle). This condition typically affects elderly individuals, particularly those over 60 years. The clinical presentation in this case is classic: dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis (foul breath), and cough with evidence of aspiration pneumonia (bilateral lung crepitations).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schatzki Ring: This is a circumferential narrowing at the gastroesophageal junction that typically causes intermittent dysphagia for solids only. It would not explain the regurgitation, halitosis, or respiratory symptoms seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Corkscrew Esophagus: This refers to diffuse esophageal spasm with non-peristaltic contractions of the esophagus. While it can cause dysphagia and chest pain, it doesn't lead to regurgitation, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia.

 

Option D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome: This is characterized by a triad of dysphagia, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs. It predominantly affects middle-aged women, not elderly men, and doesn't typically cause regurgitation, foul breath, or aspiration pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, and respiratory complications due to aspiration in an elderly patient strongly points to Zenker's diverticulum. Food collects in the pouch and can later be regurgitated, causing aspiration pneumonia.

choices.text: Laser therapy is the treatment of choice
Requires excision as it is potentially malignant
It occurs at the junction of the anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Singer's nodule? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It occurs at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd

 

Explanation:

 

Singer's nodules (also called Screamer's nodes) appear symmetrically on the free edge of vocal cords at the junction of anterior one-third with posterior two-thirds. This specific location is the area of maximum vibration of the cord during phonation, making it subject to maximum trauma. They develop due to vocal abuse or misuse when a person speaks in unnatural low tones for prolonged periods or at high intensities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laser therapy is the treatment of choice: This is incorrect. Early cases of vocal nodules are treated conservatively through voice rest and speech therapy, especially in children. Surgery is only required for large nodules or nodules of long standing in adults. Even when surgery is indicated, it can be performed either with cold instruments or laser - neither being designated as the "treatment of choice."

 

Option B. Requires excision as it is potentially malignant: This is incorrect. Singer's nodules are non-neoplastic, benign lesions that form due to trauma from vocal abuse. They have no malignant potential. They develop through a process of submucosal edema and hemorrhage that undergoes hyalinization and fibrosis.

 

Option C. Most common symptom is pain: This is incorrect. Hoarseness is the most common complaint in patients with vocal nodules. Vocal fatigue and pain in the neck on prolonged phonation may occur as secondary symptoms, but they are not the primary presenting complaint.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Singer's nodules develop at the junction of anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3 of vocal cords due to vocal abuse, primarily causing hoarseness, and are initially managed with conservative treatment including voice rest and speech therapy.

questions.text: A pure tone audiometry (PTA) result shows an air-bone gap with normal bone conduction thresholds. What is the most likely type of hearing loss? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conductive hearing loss (CHL)

 

Explanation: 


The PTA findings indicate conductive hearing loss because:

 

  • Bone conduction is normal (within 25 dB threshold).
  • Air conduction is affected (elevated threshold).
  • There is a gap between air and bone conduction curves.
  • This pattern indicates that sound transmission through the external/middle ear is impaired while inner ear function is normal.
  • The presence of air-bone gap with normal bone conduction is pathognomonic of conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)

 

  • Both air and bone conduction would be affected
  • No significant air-bone gap
  • Curves would be close to each other in affected range

 

Option C. Mixed hearing loss

 

  • Both air and bone conduction would be affected
  • Air-bone gap present but bone conduction also abnormal
  • Both curves would be in affected range with a gap between them

 

Option D. Normal hearing

 

  • Both air and bone conduction would be within normal range (≤25 dB)
  • No air-bone gap
  • Both curves would be close together in normal range

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Air-bone gap with normal bone conduction thresholds on pure tone audiometry is diagnostic of conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: All of the following are initial management options of CSF rhinorrhea except: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steroids followed by FESS

 

Steroids followed by FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery): This option is incorrect because steroids and FESS are primarily used for treating chronic rhinosinusitis and nasal polyposis. FESS is not an initial management option for CSF rhinorrhea; it is not related to repairing the skull base defect causing the CSF leak.

 

CSF rhinorrhea is the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid through the nose, often due to a defect in the skull base. Initial management focuses on conservative measures to allow spontaneous healing and to prevent complications such as meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bed rest: Advising the patient to take bed rest and avoid activities that increase intracranial pressure is a standard initial approach. This helps reduce the flow of CSF and may allow the defect to heal on its own.

 

Option C. HRCT (High-Resolution CT): HRCT is useful for diagnosing the exact site and cause of the CSF leak. It helps in planning further treatment if conservative measures fail.

 

Option D. Antibiotics and Acetazolamide: Antibiotics are given to prevent infections such as meningitis. Acetazolamide, a diuretic, reduces CSF production and intracranial pressure, which can help reduce the leak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of CSF rhinorrhea includes conservative measures such as bed rest, use of acetazolamide, and antibiotics to prevent infection. Diagnostic imaging like HRCT can help identify the defect. Steroids followed by FESS is not appropriate for the initial management of CSF rhinorrhea as it is unrelated to addressing the CSF leak.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with right-sided serous otitis media and history of cervical lymphadenopathy. The probable diagnosis is:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasopharyngeal cancer

 

Given the age of the patient and the presence of both right-sided serous otitis media and cervical lymphadenopathy, the most likely diagnosis is Nasopharyngeal cancer.

 

Nasopharyngeal cancer can present with serous otitis media due to Eustachian tube obstruction by the tumor or swollen lymph nodes in the nasopharyngeal region. Cervical lymphadenopathy is also a common finding due to the spread of the malignancy to the lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Angiofibroma, specifically juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, is a benign tumor that predominantly affects adolescent males. It can cause nasal obstruction and epistaxis (nosebleeds), but is less commonly associated with serous otitis media and is not typically diagnosed in a 50-year-old male.

 

Option C. Adenoid hypertrophy is more common in children and can cause eustachian tube dysfunction leading to serous otitis media; however, it is unlikely to be associated with cervical lymphadenopathy, especially in adults.

 

Option D. Otitis media with effusion, also known as serous otitis media, is the accumulation of fluid within the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It can be a result of eustachian tube dysfunction, which could be secondary to a mass effect from a nasopharyngeal tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When an adult patient presents with serous otitis media and cervical lymphadenopathy, it is crucial to consider nasopharyngeal cancer as a possible diagnosis, especially in the context of risk factors such as age over 50 years and a history suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text: Sludder’s neuralgia is due to compression of anterior ethmoidal nerve by septal spur in the region of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle turbinate

 

Sludder’s neuralgia, also known as anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, occurs due to the compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve. This nerve provides sensory innervation to parts of the nasal cavity and the anterior part of the cranial cavity. A septal spur, which is a sharp bony projection from the nasal septum, can impinge on the middle turbinate where the anterior ethmoidal nerve traverses. This compression can cause pain and headache in the regions supplied by the nerve, commonly leading to facial pain and nasal discomfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior turbinate: While the superior turbinate is located higher in the nasal cavity, it is not typically involved in the compression causing Sludder’s neuralgia. The anterior ethmoidal nerve runs closer to the middle turbinate.

 

Option B. Inferior turbinate: The inferior turbinate is situated lower in the nasal cavity and does not typically come into contact with the septal spur affecting the anterior ethmoidal nerve. Therefore, it is not involved in Sludder’s neuralgia.

 

Option D. Supreme turbinate: The supreme turbinate is an anatomical variant that some individuals have above the superior turbinate. This is not commonly implicated in conditions involving the anterior ethmoidal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sludder’s neuralgia, or anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, is caused by the compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve by a septal spur in the region of the middle turbinate. This condition results in facial pain and headache due to nerve irritation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old brought to the emergency department with complaints of mild bloody rhinorrhea. On examination, he was awake and oriented. Drainage has soiled his shirt, and the appearance of which is given below. This is seen in case of: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Traumatic CSF Rhinorrhea

 

Explanation: 

 

The patient presents with mild bloody rhinorrhea, and the drainage has created a characteristic "halo sign" or "double ring sign" on his shirt. This sign indicates the presence of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) mixed with blood. The halo sign is seen when CSF forms a clear ring around a central bloody spot on absorbent material. This finding is indicative of traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, where trauma causes a breach in the meninges, allowing CSF to leak and mix with nasal secretions or blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spontaneous CSF Rhinorrhea: Spontaneous CSF rhinorrhea typically involves clear CSF leakage without blood. The absence of blood would not produce the halo sign as described.

 

Option C. Meningocele: Meningocele involves herniation of the meninges through a defect in the skull or spinal column but does not typically cause nasal CSF leakage mixed with blood. It usually presents as a mass or bulge.

 

Option D. Tumors: Tumors might cause nasal discharge, but the presence of a halo sign specifically points to a CSF leak, which is more characteristic of traumatic causes rather than tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The halo sign or double ring sign on absorbent material is indicative of traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, where CSF leaks and mixes with blood, creating a central red spot surrounded by a clear or yellowish ring.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo and vomiting that is consistently triggered by turning in bed or changing head position. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vestibular neuritis

 

The combination of vertigo with vomiting triggered by positional changes is characteristic of vestibular neuritis. While BPPV also causes positional vertigo, it typically presents with vertigo alone without significant nausea and vomiting. Vestibular neuritis involves infection or inflammation of the vestibular nerve, and because these neural tracts are connected to the chemoreceptor trigger zone and vomiting centers in the brainstem, patients experience both severe vertigo and associated nausea/vomiting with head movements.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. BPPV: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo typically causes only vertigo on positional change without significant vomiting. It results from displaced otoconia in the semicircular canals causing brief episodes of vertigo.

 

Option C. Ménière's disease: This presents with a tetrad of symptoms: vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss (fluctuating), aural fullness, and tinnitus (VAST). The question doesn't mention hearing loss or ear fullness.

 

Option D. Labyrinthitis: This condition presents with vertigo plus sensorineural hearing loss but typically doesn't emphasize the positional component or prominent vomiting seen in vestibular neuritis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vestibular neuritis presents with positional vertigo accompanied by nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman from Nagaland presents with right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus. On examination, there is a dull tympanic membrane, and lymph nodes in the posterior triangle of the neck are palpable. She is from a region endemic for nasopharyngeal carcinoma. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?  (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiotherapy (RT)

 

Explanation: 


Radiotherapy is the most appropriate management because:

 

  • The presentation suggests nasopharyngeal carcinoma with: 
    • Unilateral hearing loss due to serous otitis media (dull tympanic membrane)
    • Painless cervical lymphadenopathy
    • Patient from endemic region (Nagaland)
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinomas are highly radiosensitive tumors
  • This is the first-line treatment for nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Radiotherapy provides better outcomes compared to surgery due to: 
    • Difficult surgical access to nasopharynx
    • High risk of complications with surgery
    • Rich lymphatic drainage of the area

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Radical neck dissection

 

  • Only addresses lymph node metastases
  • Doesn't treat the primary tumor
  • Not first-line treatment without prior radiotherapy

 

Option B. Grommet insertion with steroids

 

  • Only treats the secondary middle ear effusion
  • Doesn't address the underlying malignancy
  • Can be considered as supportive treatment for hearing loss

 

Option D. Wait and watch

 

  • Inappropriate for suspected malignancy
  • Delays definitive treatment
  • Can lead to disease progression

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Radiotherapy is the primary treatment modality for nasopharyngeal carcinoma due to the tumor's high radiosensitivity and anatomical considerations.

 

Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

questions.text: Type of tympanoplasty shown in image Below: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type 4

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows Type 4 tympanoplasty (Wullstein classification) where:

 

  • The graft is placed directly on the stapes footplate
  • All ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes suprastructure) are absent
  • Only the footplate remains
  • Also called cavum minor tympanoplasty

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1

 

  • Simple myringoplasty with intact ossicular chain
  • Graft placed on handle of malleus
  • All ossicles are present and functional

 

Option B. Type 2

 

  • Graft placed on incus or remnant of malleus
  • Partial ossicular defect
  • Malleus absent but incus present

 

Option C. Type 3

 

  • Also called columella tympanoplasty
  • Graft placed on stapes head
  • Malleus and incus absent but stapes suprastructure present

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize Type 4 tympanoplasty as the procedure where the tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes footplate when all ossicles are absent except the footplate.

 

Tympanoplasty –

questions.text: A person presents in ENT OPD having nasal blockage with crusts, foul-smelling discharge, and hyposmia. On examination, nose is hard, and biopsy reveals following histopathological findings. What is the likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of nasal blockage, crusts, foul-smelling discharge, and hyposmia, along with the finding of a hard nose and the specific histopathological findings in the biopsy (such as Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies), are indicative of rhinoscleroma caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous condition that leads to the hardening of the nasal tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinosporidium seeberi: This condition would show sporangia containing endospores on histopathology, which is not seen in this case.

 

 

Option B. Klebsiella ozaenae: Typically causes atrophic rhinitis characterized by foul-smelling discharge and crusting, but it does not cause a hard nose or the specific histopathological findings seen here.

 

 

Option D. Autoimmunity: Autoimmune conditions can cause nasal symptoms but are not characterized by the specific histopathological findings of Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinoscleroma, caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, presents with a hard nose, nasal blockage, crusting, foul-smelling discharge, and specific histopathological findings such as Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies.

questions.text: A boy with ASOM underwent treatment for the same. Now he presents with subsidence of pain but persistence of deafness. On examination of TM, the following findings are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secretory otitis media

 

Explanation:

 

The boy has undergone treatment for Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) and now presents with subsidence of pain but persistence of deafness. The otoscopic examination reveals air-fluid levels behind an intact tympanic membrane, indicative of fluid in the middle ear. This condition is known as secretory otitis media (also called otitis media with effusion), where the middle ear is filled with sterile fluid, leading to conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ototoxicity: Ototoxicity refers to damage to the inner ear structures, particularly the hair cells, due to exposure to certain ototoxic drugs (e.g., aminoglycosides, loop diuretics, cisplatin). This results in sensorineural hearing loss and is not characterized by air-fluid levels in the middle ear.

 

Option C. Adhesive otitis media: Adhesive otitis media is characterized by the retraction of the tympanic membrane, which adheres to the medial wall of the middle ear. This condition results from chronic eustachian tube dysfunction and does not typically present with air-fluid levels as seen in secretory otitis media.

 

 

Option D. Tympanosclerosis: Tympanosclerosis involves the formation of calcium plaques within the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane or middle ear due to recurrent infections. This leads to stiffening of the tympanic membrane and conductive hearing loss. The otoscopic findings show calcific deposits, not fluid levels.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory otitis media is characterized by the presence of sterile fluid in the middle ear, resulting in conductive hearing loss, and is often seen following the treatment of ASOM.

questions.text: Identify the blocked structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinus

 

The image shows a coronal CT scan of the sinuses, where a blocked structure is indicated by the arrow. The blockage appears to be in the maxillary sinus, which is characterized by the presence of an antrochoanal polyp. Antrochoanal polyps originate in the maxillary sinus and extend into the nasal cavity, typically passing through the middle meatus. In this case, the blockage is in the maxillary sinus, as evidenced by the extension of the polyp towards the middle meatus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ethmoid sinus: This is incorrect because the ethmoid sinus is located medially and superiorly to the maxillary sinus and does not match the position of the blockage shown in the image.

  

Option C. Frontal sinus: This is incorrect as the frontal sinus is located above the eyes and towards the forehead, which is not indicated as blocked in the image.

 Option D. Sphenoid sinus: This is incorrect because the sphenoid sinus is located deeper within the skull, behind the ethmoid sinuses, and is not the blocked area shown.

    

Educational Objective:

 

The maxillary sinus can be blocked by an antrochoanal polyp that extends into the nasal cavity through the middle meatus.

questions.text: A child was brought to ENT OPD with complaints of mouth breathing and snoring from a long duration. He also asks to increase the volume of TV while watching. What is the best treatment for this child’s condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenoidectomy and grommet

 

The child presents with symptoms of mouth breathing and snoring, which are indicative of adenoid hypertrophy. The request to increase the TV volume suggests a hearing problem, likely due to conductive hearing loss caused by chronic adenoiditis with adenoid hypertrophy. Enlarged adenoids can obstruct the Eustachian tube, leading to fluid accumulation in the middle ear, known as otitis media with effusion. This condition causes conductive hearing loss.

 

Adenoidectomy involves the surgical removal of the adenoids to alleviate the obstruction. Inserting a grommet (tympanostomy tube) allows for drainage of the middle ear fluid, improving hearing and preventing recurrent otitis media.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoidectomy: While this addresses the adenoid hypertrophy, it does not address the fluid accumulation in the middle ear. The addition of a grommet is necessary for complete management.

 

Option B. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone would not resolve the underlying issue of adenoid hypertrophy and chronic Eustachian tube obstruction.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach would not be suitable given the chronic nature of the symptoms and the associated hearing loss. Delaying treatment could lead to further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of chronic adenoid hypertrophy causing mouth breathing, snoring, and conductive hearing loss, the best treatment involves adenoidectomy along with the insertion of a grommet to ensure proper drainage of middle ear fluid and restore normal hearing.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with hearing loss. On examination, a white pearly mass is seen behind an intact TM as shown below. There is no history of TM perforation or surgery. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital cholesteatoma

 

Explanation: 

 

The presence of a white pearly mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in a young child with no history of tympanic membrane perforation or surgery strongly suggests congenital cholesteatoma. Congenital cholesteatoma occurs due to the presence of residual epithelial cells trapped within the middle ear during embryogenesis, which later proliferate. This condition is typically seen in the anterosuperior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary cholesteatoma: Primary cholesteatoma usually involves a retraction pocket and is associated with a history of eustachian tube dysfunction. It is not typically seen with an intact tympanic membrane without a history of perforation or retraction.

 

Option C. Secondary cholesteatoma: Secondary cholesteatoma arises due to chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) with tympanic membrane perforation or from a previous surgical procedure. It does not present with an intact tympanic membrane.

 

Option D. Tubotympanic CSOM: Tubotympanic chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is associated with a central perforation of the tympanic membrane and chronic discharge. It is not consistent with an intact tympanic membrane and a white pearly mass.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Congenital cholesteatoma is characterized by a white pearly mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in the absence of any history of perforation or surgery. It is typically found in the anterosuperior quadrant of the middle ear.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with painless cervical lymphadenopathy. During the examination, the right ear shows conductive hearing loss, and the tympanic membrane appears dull. Additionally, reduced mobility of the soft palate is noted. What could be the likely diagnosis for these findings?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

 

Given clinical condition is suggestive of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenoid cystic cancer: Typically involves salivary glands, not commonly associated with the described ear and nasopharyngeal symptoms.

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Mostly affects adolescent males and is a benign tumor, which would not usually present with the described range of symptoms including lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Quinsy: Refers to a peritonsillar abscess, primarily presenting with severe throat pain, unilateral sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing, differing significantly from the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a serious condition requiring prompt diagnosis and comprehensive treatment, given its potential for significant morbidity due to local invasion and distant metastasis. The clinical findings provided are strongly indicative of this diagnosis and warrant further confirmatory diagnostics, such as imaging and biopsy, followed by an appropriate oncological treatment regimen.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 284,285

questions.text: A child as shown below presented to the ENT department with the following finding. She gives complaint of recurrent bony fractures along with reduced hearing. On further investigation, Tympanometry showed the following finding. What would you name this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Van der Hoeve syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The child presents with recurrent bony fractures and reduced hearing, which are indicative of osteogenesis imperfecta (imperfectly developed bones).

 

The tympanometry shows an AS type of curve, suggesting otosclerosis.
